content.content: 1. (1) In this Regulation, “effective date” means the date on which the Liquor Licence Act is repealed. (2) Words and expressions used in this Regulation have the same meanings as in Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) and Ontario Regulation 747/21 (Permits), both made under the Act.
content.raw_html:
1. (1) In this Regulation,

“effective date” means the date on which the Liquor Licence Act is repealed.

(2) Words and expressions used in this Regulation have the same meanings as in Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) and Ontario Regulation 747/21 (Permits), both made under the Act.

content.section: Liquor Licence Act licences, permits and endorsements
content.content: 2. (1) Licences, permits and endorsements that were issued and in force under the Liquor Licence Act immediately before the effective date are continued under the Act in accordance with this section. (2) The following licences under the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued as follows: 1.  Subject to paragraph 4, a liquor sales licence described in paragraph 1 of subsection 8 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a liquor sales licence. 2.  A mini bar licence described in paragraph 2 of subsection 8 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a mini bar licence. 3.  A licence to sell liquor described in subsection 2 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a liquor sales licence. 4.  A licence to sell liquor described in section 2.1 of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a by-the-glass endorsement on the brewery licence, distillery licence or winery licence of the manufacturer who held the licence to sell liquor. 5.  A licence to deliver liquor issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to deliver. 6.  A licence to represent a manufacturer issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to represent a manufacturer. 7.  A licence to operate a ferment on premise facility issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to operate a ferment on premises facility. 8.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell beer issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a brewery licence. 9.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell spirits issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a distillery licence. 10.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell wine issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a winery licence. (3) The following permits that were issued by the Registrar under subsection 19 (6) of the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued as follows: 1.  A sales permit described in paragraph 1 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a sale permit. 2.  A no-sale permit described in paragraph 2 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a no-sale permit. 3.  A permit issued for a tailgate event described in paragraph 3 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, that authorizes the sale and service of liquor is continued as a sale tailgate permit. 4.  A permit issued for a tailgate event described in paragraph 3 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, that does not authorize the sale and service of liquor is continued as a no-sale tailgate permit. (4) The following endorsements to liquor sales licences described in Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as an endorsement on the former endorsement holder’s continued liquor sales licence as follows: 1.  A brew pub endorsement described in paragraph 1 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a brew pub endorsement. 2.  A wine pub endorsement described in paragraph 2 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine pub endorsement. 3.  A caterer’s endorsement described in paragraph 3 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a caterer’s endorsement. 4.  A room service endorsement described in paragraph 4 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a room service endorsement. 5.  A mini bar endorsement described in paragraph 5 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a mini bar endorsement. 6.  A golf course endorsement described in paragraph 6 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a golf course endorsement. 7.  A bring-your-own wine endorsement described in paragraph 8 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a bring-your-own-wine endorsement.
content.raw_html:
2. (1) Licences, permits and endorsements that were issued and in force under the Liquor Licence Act immediately before the effective date are continued under the Act in accordance with this section.

(2) The following licences under the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued as follows:

1.  Subject to paragraph 4, a liquor sales licence described in paragraph 1 of subsection 8 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a liquor sales licence.

2.  A mini bar licence described in paragraph 2 of subsection 8 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a mini bar licence.

3.  A licence to sell liquor described in subsection 2 (1) of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a liquor sales licence.

4.  A licence to sell liquor described in section 2.1 of Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a by-the-glass endorsement on the brewery licence, distillery licence or winery licence of the manufacturer who held the licence to sell liquor.

5.  A licence to deliver liquor issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to deliver.

6.  A licence to represent a manufacturer issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to represent a manufacturer.

7.  A licence to operate a ferment on premise facility issued by the Registrar under subsection 12 (1) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a licence to operate a ferment on premises facility.

8.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell beer issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a brewery licence.

9.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell spirits issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a distillery licence.

10.  A manufacturer’s licence to sell wine issued by the Registrar under subsection 22 (2) of that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a winery licence.

(3) The following permits that were issued by the Registrar under subsection 19 (6) of the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued as follows:

1.  A sales permit described in paragraph 1 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a sale permit.

2.  A no-sale permit described in paragraph 2 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, is continued as a no-sale permit.

3.  A permit issued for a tailgate event described in paragraph 3 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, that authorizes the sale and service of liquor is continued as a sale tailgate permit.

4.  A permit issued for a tailgate event described in paragraph 3 of section 2 of Ontario Regulation 389/91 (Special Occasion Permits) made under that Act, as it read at the time, that does not authorize the sale and service of liquor is continued as a no-sale tailgate permit.

(4) The following endorsements to liquor sales licences described in Regulation 719 of the Revised Regulations of Ontario (Licences to Sell Liquor) made under the Liquor Licence Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as an endorsement on the former endorsement holder’s continued liquor sales licence as follows:

1.  A brew pub endorsement described in paragraph 1 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a brew pub endorsement.

2.  A wine pub endorsement described in paragraph 2 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine pub endorsement.

3.  A caterer’s endorsement described in paragraph 3 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a caterer’s endorsement.

4.  A room service endorsement described in paragraph 4 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a room service endorsement.

5.  A mini bar endorsement described in paragraph 5 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a mini bar endorsement.

6.  A golf course endorsement described in paragraph 6 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a golf course endorsement.

7.  A bring-your-own wine endorsement described in paragraph 8 of subsection 8 (2) of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a bring-your-own-wine endorsement.

content.content:
3. (1) Authorizations under the Liquor Control Act that were granted and in force immediately before the effective date are continued under the Act in accordance with this section. (2) The following authorizations under clause 3 (1) (e) of the Liquor Control Act are continued under the Act as follows: 1.  An authorization granted to a beer manufacturer to sell their beer in stores owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a brewery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s brewery licence. 2.  An authorization granted to a spirits manufacturer to sell their spirits in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a distillery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s distillery licence. 3.  Subject to subsection (3), an authorization granted to a wine manufacturer to sell their Ontario wine in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a winery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s winery licence in the following subclass: i.  In the case of an on-site grape winery retail store authorization, the grape winery retail store subclass. ii.  In the case of an on-site fruit winery retail store authorization, the fruit winery retail store subclass. iii.  In the case of an on-site honey winery retail store authorization, the honey winery retail store subclass. iv.  In the case of an on-site retail store— other winery authorization under which maple wine was sold, the maple winery retail store subclass. v.  In the case of an on-site retail store — other winery authorization under which sake was sold, the sake retail store subclass. 4.  An authorization granted to a wine manufacturer to sell their Ontario wine in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer that is not located at its production site is continued as an offsite winery retail store licence. 5.  An authorization granted to a manufacturer to sell spirits, beer or Ontario wine at an occasional extension of a distillery retail store, brewery retail store or winery retail store within a farmers’ market is continued as a temporary extension endorsement on the manufacturer’s distillery licence, brewery licence or winery licence, as applicable. (3) If a person held multiple authorizations described in paragraph 3 of subsection (2), they shall be continued as a single winery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s winery licence in each of the applicable subclasses described in that paragraph. (4) The authorization granted to Brewers Retail Inc. to operate stores for the sale of beer to the public under clause 3 (1) (e) of the Liquor Control Act
is continued under the Act as the Brewers Retail Inc. licence. (5) Any approval of a Brewers Retail Inc. store location under section 6 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, is continued under the Act as an approval of the store location under the Brewers Retail Inc. licence described in subsection (4). (6) Authorizations established in connection with the sale of beer and wine in grocery stores and listed in section 9 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as follows: 1.  A beer and cider authorization described in paragraph 1 of section 9 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a beer and cider grocery store licence. 2.  A beer and wine authorization described in paragraph 2 of section 9 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a beer and wine grocery store licence. (7) Authorizations established in connection with the sale of wine in wine boutiques and listed in section 28.1 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as follows: 1.  A supplementary wine authorization described in paragraph 1 of section 28.1 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine boutique endorsement on the offsite winery retail store licence held by the winery for the store to which the authorization applied. 2.  An authorization as a wine boutique sales agent described in paragraph 2 of section 28.1 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine boutique sales agent endorsement on the beer and cider grocery store licence held by the authorized person for the store to which the authorization applied. (8) An auction authorization granted by the Registrar under clause 3 (1) (b) of the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, is continued under the Act as an auction permit.
content.raw_html:
3. (1) Authorizations under the Liquor Control Act that were granted and in force immediately before the effective date are continued under the Act in accordance with this section.

(2) The following authorizations under clause 3 (1) (e) of the Liquor Control Act are continued under the Act as follows:

1.  An authorization granted to a beer manufacturer to sell their beer in stores owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a brewery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s brewery licence.

2.  An authorization granted to a spirits manufacturer to sell their spirits in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a distillery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s distillery licence.

3.  Subject to subsection (3), an authorization granted to a wine manufacturer to sell their Ontario wine in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site is continued as a winery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s winery licence in the following subclass:

i.  In the case of an on-site grape winery retail store authorization, the grape winery retail store subclass.

ii.  In the case of an on-site fruit winery retail store authorization, the fruit winery retail store subclass.

iii.  In the case of an on-site honey winery retail store authorization, the honey winery retail store subclass.

iv.  In the case of an on-site retail store— other winery authorization under which maple wine was sold, the maple winery retail store subclass.

v.  In the case of an on-site retail store — other winery authorization under which sake was sold, the sake retail store subclass.

4.  An authorization granted to a wine manufacturer to sell their Ontario wine in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer that is not located at its production site is continued as an offsite winery retail store licence.

5.  An authorization granted to a manufacturer to sell spirits, beer or Ontario wine at an occasional extension of a distillery retail store, brewery retail store or winery retail store within a farmers’ market is continued as a temporary extension endorsement on the manufacturer’s distillery licence, brewery licence or winery licence, as applicable.

(3) If a person held multiple authorizations described in paragraph 3 of subsection (2), they shall be continued as a single winery retail store endorsement on the manufacturer’s winery licence in each of the applicable subclasses described in that paragraph.

(4) The authorization granted to Brewers Retail Inc. to operate stores for the sale of beer to the public under clause 3 (1) (e) of the Liquor Control Act is continued under the Act as the Brewers Retail Inc. licence.

(5) Any approval of a Brewers Retail Inc. store location under section 6 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, is continued under the Act as an approval of the store location under the Brewers Retail Inc. licence described in subsection (4).

(6) Authorizations established in connection with the sale of beer and wine in grocery stores and listed in section 9 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as follows:

1.  A beer and cider authorization described in paragraph 1 of section 9 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a beer and cider grocery store licence.

2.  A beer and wine authorization described in paragraph 2 of section 9 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a beer and wine grocery store licence.

(7) Authorizations established in connection with the sale of wine in wine boutiques and listed in section 28.1 of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, are continued under the Act as follows:

1.  A supplementary wine authorization described in paragraph 1 of section 28.1 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine boutique endorsement on the offsite winery retail store licence held by the winery for the store to which the authorization applied.

2.  An authorization as a wine boutique sales agent described in paragraph 2 of section 28.1 of that Regulation, as it read at the time, is continued as a wine boutique sales agent endorsement on the beer and cider grocery store licence held by the authorized person for the store to which the authorization applied.

(8) An auction authorization granted by the Registrar under clause 3 (1) (b) of the Liquor Control Act, as it read at the time, is continued under the Act as an auction permit.

content.content: 4. (1) Any conditions that were attached to a licence or permit under the Liquor Licence Act shall be deemed to have been imposed on the relevant licence, endorsement or permit that it was continued as under this Regulation, with necessary modifications. (2) Subject to subsection (3), any conditions that were attached to an authorization that was granted under the Liquor Control Act do not continue on the licence, endorsement or permit that the authorization was continued as under this Regulation. (3) Any condition on an authorization that was granted to a spirits manufacturer to sell their spirits in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site that required the manufacturer to employ a certain number of staff members in Ontario or have at its production site certain types of equipment is deemed to have been imposed on the manufacturer’s licence to sell that was continued under this Regulation. (4) A holder of a manufacturer’s licence to sell that is subject to a condition that was continued under subsection (3) is exempt from paragraph 2 of subsection 144 (2) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.
content.raw_html:
4. (1) Any conditions that were attached to a licence or permit under the Liquor Licence Act shall be deemed to have been imposed on the relevant licence, endorsement or permit that it was continued as under this Regulation, with necessary modifications.

(2) Subject to subsection (3), any conditions that were attached to an authorization that was granted under the Liquor Control Act do not continue on the licence, endorsement or permit that the authorization was continued as under this Regulation.

(3) Any condition on an authorization that was granted to a spirits manufacturer to sell their spirits in a store owned and operated by the manufacturer and located at its production site that required the manufacturer to employ a certain number of staff members in Ontario or have at its production site certain types of equipment is deemed to have been imposed on the manufacturer’s licence to sell that was continued under this Regulation.

(4) A holder of a manufacturer’s licence to sell that is subject to a condition that was continued under subsection (3) is exempt from paragraph 2 of subsection 144 (2) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.

content.content: 5. (1) The appointments of any vendors of sacramental wines that were made by the LCBO under clause 3 (1) (k) of the Liquor Control Act and in force immediately before the effective date are continued until July 1, 2028. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (1); O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (1). (2) Any terms and conditions that applied to an appointment of a vendor of sacramental wine under the Liquor Control Act continue to apply to the appointment. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (2). (2.1) The following powers that the LCBO had under the Liquor Control Act are continued until July 1, 2028: 1.  The power to appoint vendors to keep for sale, offer for sale or sell sacramental wine, in accordance with any terms and conditions imposed by the LCBO. 2.  The power to make changes and additions to the terms and conditions that apply to an appointment of a vendor of sacramental wine. O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (2). (3) The LCBO may revoke an appointment that was continued under subsection (1) or made in accordance with the powers continued under subsection (2.1) if the vendor does not comply with the terms and conditions of the appointment. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (3); O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (3). (4) Until July 1, 2028, vendors of sacramental wine whose appointments were continued under subsection (1), or who were appointed in accordance with the powers continued under subsection (2.1), and whose appointments have not been revoked or surrendered are exempt from the requirements of subsection 2 (1) of the Act in respect of keeping for sale, offering for sale or selling sacramental wine. O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (4).
content.raw_html:
5. (1) The appointments of any vendors of sacramental wines that were made by the LCBO under clause 3 (1) (k) of the Liquor Control Act and in force immediately before the effective date are continued until July 1, 2028. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (1); O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (1).

(2) Any terms and conditions that applied to an appointment of a vendor of sacramental wine under the Liquor Control Act continue to apply to the appointment. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (2).

(2.1) The following powers that the LCBO had under the Liquor Control Act are continued until July 1, 2028:

1.  The power to appoint vendors to keep for sale, offer for sale or sell sacramental wine, in accordance with any terms and conditions imposed by the LCBO.

2.  The power to make changes and additions to the terms and conditions that apply to an appointment of a vendor of sacramental wine. O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (2).

(3) The LCBO may revoke an appointment that was continued under subsection (1) or made in accordance with the powers continued under subsection (2.1) if the vendor does not comply with the terms and conditions of the appointment. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 5 (3); O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (3).

(4) Until July 1, 2028, vendors of sacramental wine whose appointments were continued under subsection (1), or who were appointed in accordance with the powers continued under subsection (2.1), and whose appointments have not been revoked or surrendered are exempt from the requirements of subsection 2 (1) of the Act in respect of keeping for sale, offering for sale or selling sacramental wine. O. Reg. 176/23, s. 1 (4).

content.content: 6. (1) Any application for a licence, endorsement, authorization or permit that was submitted under the Liquor Licence Act or the Liquor Control Act but that was not finally determined before the effective date is deemed to have been made under the Act. (2) The Registrar shall treat the application as if it were made for the licence, endorsement or permit that the licensee would have been entitled to under this Regulation if the application had been granted before the effective date. (3) Despite subsection (2), the Registrar shall consider the application on the basis of the eligibility and ineligibility criteria that applied under the Liquor Licence Act or the Liquor Control Act, as applicable, at the time the application was submitted.
content.raw_html:
6. (1) Any application for a licence, endorsement, authorization or permit that was submitted under the Liquor Licence Act or the Liquor Control Act but that was not finally determined before the effective date is deemed to have been made under the Act.

(2) The Registrar shall treat the application as if it were made for the licence, endorsement or permit that the licensee would have been entitled to under this Regulation if the application had been granted before the effective date.

(3) Despite subsection (2), the Registrar shall consider the application on the basis of the eligibility and ineligibility criteria that applied under the Liquor Licence Act or the Liquor Control Act, as applicable, at the time the application was submitted.

content.content:
7. (1) An inspection that began under subsection 44 (1) of the Liquor Licence Act or Part II of the Liquor Control Act
but that was not completed by the effective date shall continue as an inspection under section 55 of the Act. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (1). (2) An inspection for which a warrant was issued under the Liquor Licence Act
or the Liquor Control Act that was not completed by the effective date shall be continued as an investigation under section 56 of the Act. O. Reg. 802/21, s. 1. (3) A notice of proposal issued under section 21 of the Liquor Licence Act
or section 3.0.3 of the Liquor Control Act in respect of a licence or authorization is continued as a notice of proposal issued under section 25 of the Act, with necessary modifications, in respect of, (a)  in the case of a licence or authorization that was continued as a licence, the continued licence; or (b)  in the case of an authorization that was continued as an endorsement, the licence with that endorsement. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (3). (4) A request for a hearing by the Tribunal in respect of a notice of proposal under the Liquor Licence Act is continued as a request for a hearing by the Tribunal under the Act, with necessary modifications. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (4). (5) A hearing under section 23 of the Liquor Licence Act or section 3.0.3 of the Liquor Control Act is continued as a hearing under section 26 of the Act, with necessary modifications. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (5). (6) Subject to subsection (8), a licence suspension issued under the Liquor Licence Act
is continued as a suspension under the Act of the continued licence or of the endorsement that the licence was continued as. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (6). (7) Subject to subsection (8), a suspension of an authorization granted under the Liquor Control Act is continued as a suspension under the Act of the licence or endorsement that the authorization was continued as. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (7). (8) An interim suspension before a hearing under subsection 15 (6) of the Liquor Licence Act or subsection 3.0.1 (2) of the Liquor Control Act is continued as a suspension before a hearing under subsection 13 (2) of the Act. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (8).
content.raw_html:
7. (1) An inspection that began under subsection 44 (1) of the Liquor Licence Act or Part II of the Liquor Control Act but that was not completed by the effective date shall continue as an inspection under section 55 of the Act. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (1).

(2) An inspection for which a warrant was issued under the Liquor Licence Act or the Liquor Control Act that was not completed by the effective date shall be continued as an investigation under section 56 of the Act. O. Reg. 802/21, s. 1.

(3) A notice of proposal issued under section 21 of the Liquor Licence Act or section 3.0.3 of the Liquor Control Act in respect of a licence or authorization is continued as a notice of proposal issued under section 25 of the Act, with necessary modifications, in respect of,

(a)  in the case of a licence or authorization that was continued as a licence, the continued licence; or

(b)  in the case of an authorization that was continued as an endorsement, the licence with that endorsement. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (3).

(4) A request for a hearing by the Tribunal in respect of a notice of proposal under the Liquor Licence Act is continued as a request for a hearing by the Tribunal under the Act, with necessary modifications. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (4).

(5) A hearing under section 23 of the Liquor Licence Act or section 3.0.3 of the Liquor Control Act is continued as a hearing under section 26 of the Act, with necessary modifications. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (5).

(6) Subject to subsection (8), a licence suspension issued under the Liquor Licence Act is continued as a suspension under the Act of the continued licence or of the endorsement that the licence was continued as. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (6).

(7) Subject to subsection (8), a suspension of an authorization granted under the Liquor Control Act is continued as a suspension under the Act of the licence or endorsement that the authorization was continued as. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (7).

(8) An interim suspension before a hearing under subsection 15 (6) of the Liquor Licence Act or subsection 3.0.1 (2) of the Liquor Control Act is continued as a suspension before a hearing under subsection 13 (2) of the Act. O. Reg. 767/21, s. 7 (8).

content.content: 8. A notification provided in writing to the Liquor Control Board of Ontario for the purposes of subsection 31 (1) of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read immediately before the effective date, is deemed to be a notification provided in writing to the Registrar for the purposes of subsection 155 (8) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.
content.raw_html: 8. A notification provided in writing to the Liquor Control Board of Ontario for the purposes of subsection 31 (1) of Ontario Regulation 232/16 (Sale of Liquor in Government Stores) made under the Liquor Control Act, as it read immediately before the effective date, is deemed to be a notification provided in writing to the Registrar for the purposes of subsection 155 (8) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.

content.content: 9. Any wine that was manufactured before the day the Wine Content and Labelling Act, 2000 was repealed and that could have been sold under that Act is deemed to be in compliance with paragraph 2 of subsection 138 (2) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.
content.raw_html: 9. Any wine that was manufactured before the day the Wine Content and Labelling Act, 2000 was repealed and that could have been sold under that Act is deemed to be in compliance with paragraph 2 of subsection 138 (2) of Ontario Regulation 746/21 (Licensing) made under the Act.

content.content: 10. Omitted (provides for coming into force of provisions of this Regulation).
content.raw_html: 10. Omitted (provides for coming into force of provisions of this Regulation).
